Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2017 IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM) is a premier international conference, which covers a wide spectrum of theoretical and applied research in networking field and provides a unique platform for world-leading researchers and practitioners to present their latest research results. Attending such a high-caliber technical venue is important for graduate students' professional development. The students will have the opportunity to present their work, and be exposed to the state-of-the-art in the field. They will also have the opportunity to interact with peers from institutions worldwide, meet with leading researchers, and involve in discussions that are likely to shape the future of the field.

This award will support approximately 25 students in the United States to attend the 2017 IEEE INFOCOM conference which will be held in Atlanta, Georgia, USA from May 1 to May 4, 2017. The travel grants will target graduate students who will substantially benefit from attending this conference but have limited travel funds. Priority will be given to female and underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 IEEE INFOCOM Conference on Computer Communications was held in Atlanta, USA from May 1 to May 4, 2017. This preeminent technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of computer communications, and is widely attended by researchers and practitioners in the field. The program consists of technical sessions, workshops, panels, and tutorials. The acceptance rate of INFOCOM 2017 was 20.9% (typically between 17% and 22% since 2004), which indicates the high quality of the conference. Due to the high volume of submissions from the US, the participation level from US participants was high: the conference had more than 1,000 participants from more than 40 countries, and more than half of the participants were from US. Attending such a high-caliber conference is extremely valuable for graduate students’ education and long-term career development. By providing the travel support, this project contributes to the training of the future researchers in the field of computer communications and networking.

This project provided funding support to 25 graduate students in the United States to attend this premiere conference. Among all the applicants, 46% were selected to receive the travel support, with priorities given to women, under-represented minority students, and students who would substantially benefit from attending the conference. All awardees had at least one paper being accepted by INFOCOM 2017 and attended the conference as the presenter of the paper. Out of the 25 awardees from 15 states and 20 universities, 4 are female students, two thirds are in the middle of their doctoral program, and most of the awardees are first-time attendees. The awards were decided by the award selection committee consisting of two professors, and conflicts-of-interest have been avoided during the selection process.

The awardees expressed their deep appreciation for the NSF travel support and acknowledged the great value and importance of attending the conference. They not only had the opportunities of presenting their work, learning the state-of-the-art research, participating panel discussions, but also were able to meet new colleagues, and interact with hundreds of others performing cutting-edge research in the field.
